questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis based on the supine abdominal radiograph ?
questions.solution:
• Supine radiograph shows a distended upturned cecum with the configuration of a reversed letter C.
  • Cecal volvulus is less common and occurs in slightly younger patients than sigmoid volvulus
  • Cecal volvulus shows presence of haustrations and associated SBO
  • Cecal volvulus shows 1 distended loop with haustra

questions.text: Invertogram is used in?
questions.solution:
• The invertogram view is a radiograph often used exclusively in characterizing anal atresia in paediatric population.
  • It should be done 24 hrs after birth

questions.text: A 51-year-old man with a history of smoking presented with pain in the right arm. There is also evidence of ptosis and Horner's syndrome. Chest X ray is given below. Diagnosis?
questions.solution: Pancoast tumor is the tumor of the lung apex which presents with various symptoms. The most common of them being shoulder pain due to involvement of brachial plexus. The drooping of eyelids and horner syndrome occurs due to involvement of sympathetic nerve roots.

questions.text: A 23 old female on treatment for infertility develops severe abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting. USG reveals the following appearance. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution: Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is a potentially life-threatening complication of ovulation induction or ovarian stimulation. It occurs during the luteal phase of menstrual cycle or in early pregnancy and mostly follows administration of endogenous or exogenous LH or hCG. It occurs after hCG administration to patient with a large number of immature follicles and high serum estradiol levels and is more likely to occur in those with a polycystic ovarian morphology. Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome results when hyperstimulation of the ovaries is associated with an aberration of the fluid balance. It is characterized by third-space fluid accumulation and electrolyte abnormalities. On imaging, symmetric enlargement of bilateral ovaries is seen which contain multiple cystic areas of varying sizes which represent enlarged follicles or corpus luteal cysts in the presence of ascites. The "spoke wheel" appearance has been described with peripherally located follicles surrounding a central core of ovarian stroma. The cysts are usually anechoic but may contain hemorrhage.

choices.text: Increased uptake because of osteoblastic lesion

questions.text: A Patient with history of prostate carcinoma. High Gleason score bone scan done show increased uptake with bone and reduced in kidney and soft tissue. This is reported as super scan. The reason behind it is?
questions.solution:
When interpreting skeletal scintigraphy, the term "superscan" refers to a characteristic pattern consisting of symmetrically intense and diffuse radiotracer uptake in the skeleton with absent or diminished visualization of the genitourinary system and soft tissues. This appearance can lead to false-negative scans for metastasis because the diffuse and symmetric skeletal uptake may obscure individual metastatic foci. It as been hypothesized that increased uptake of radiopharmaceutical by involved bone led to reduced phosphate excretion and diminution of renal activity. The differential diagnosis pertaining to a superscan pattern on skeletal scintigraphy includes diffuse osteoblastic metastasis, renal osteodystrophy, osteomalacia, and severe primary hyperparathyroidism

Reference: Manov JJ, Roth PJ, Kuker R. Clinical Pearls: Etiologies of Superscan Appearance on Fluorine-18-Fludeoxyglucose Positron Emission Tomography-Computed Tomography. Indian J Nucl Med. 2017 Oct-Dec;32(4):259-265. doi: 10.4103/ijnm.IJNM_56_17. PMID: 29142340; PMCID: PMC5672744.

questions.text: A middle aged male patient presented with acute onset pain in right limb. An investigation was performed. What is the name of the investigation?
questions.solution: Ultrasonography with color Doppler is another modality which can be of use in the evaluation of PVD. Apart from the grayscale (B mode), Doppler principle can be used to overlay color and generate graphical spectrum of the flow dynamics. Normal extremity artery shows a triphasic high resistance flow pattern with a preserved spectral window.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presenting with chronic low back pain and early morning stiffness since last 2 years associated with bilateral heel pains. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic, progressive inflammatory arthritis which chiefly involves the synovial joints of the spine along with the adjacent soft tissues as well as the sacroiliac joints, although peripheral, large joints such as the hips, shoulders and knee can also be involved.

Radiological features:

SI joints: The classic sacroiliitis is bilateral and symmetrical. Changes occur in both the synovial along with ligamentous (superior and posterior) parts of the sacroiliac joints. The earliest radiographic findings occur in the subchondral cortex which appears blurred or lost. Later, small (rat-bite) erosions appear which are worse along the iliac aspect of the joint. These cause widening of the joint space with hazy margins. This is followed by larger erosions, subjacent sclerosis and joint space narrowing as irregular new bone bridges the joint space with eventual ankylosis and resolution of the sclerosis. The modified New York criteria is used for grading of sacroiliitis and was established in 1994.

Spine: Spinal involvement classically starts at the dorsolumbar or lumbosacral junction with subsequent progressive involvement of the rest of the spine in an ascending manner. Erosions initially occur at the vertebral margins at the site of attachment of the outer fibers of the annulus fibrosus (Romanus lesions) with adjacent sclerosis (shiny corner sign). Healing of these erosions or laying down of bone beneath the anterior longitudinal ligament causes "squaring" of the vertebral bodies, best appreciated on lateral radiographs of the lumbar spine. Exuberant new bone formation may even cause anterior convexity of the vertebral body (barrel-shaped vertebrae). As the disease progresses, there is syndesmophyte formation along the anterior and anterolateral aspects of the body due to ossification in the annulus. Similar ossifications may be seen in the interspinous ligaments and facet joints causing the dagger and tram-track signs respectively. Facet joint ankylosis is the major factor causing loss of spinal mobility.

questions.text: A 45 year old female having HIV prescribed ergotamine for migraine attacks, developed acute pain in mid-thigh with non-palpable dorsalis pedis. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ergotamine has been used widely for the treatment of migraine. Ergotism is a sustained vasospasm induced by ergot medication, and is very rare, but has been observed in various situations, mainly as a result of ergotamine overuse, idiosyncratic hypersensitivity reaction with therapeutic doses, and during concomitant use of other kinds of medication.The given angiographic images shows non opacification of the peripheral vessels which is suggestive of reduced blood flow. In patient with history of ergotamine, it is suggestive of vasospasm/ ergotism.

Reference: Jeong SY, Lim ES, Shin BS, Seo MW, Kim YH, Kwak HS, Chung GH, Jeong SK. Ergotism with ischemia in all four extremities: a case report. J Clin Neurol. 2006 Dec;2(4):279-82. doi: 10.3988/jcn.2006.2.4.279. Epub 2006 Dec 20. PMID: 20396534; PMCID: PMC2854981.

questions.text: A 45 year old male presented with backache since 20 years and difficulty during neck movements. Most likely diagnosis based on this cervical spine radiograph is?
questions.solution:
DISH, often referred to as Forestier disease, is a common disorder found in the late middle aged/ elderly with an unknown etiology. It is characterized by marked hyperosteosis seen at multiple sites, but classically involving the spine. There is multilevel spinal involvement with flowing ligamentous ossifications.

The diagnostic criteria for DISH are:

  • Presence of ossification along the anterolateral aspect of at least four contiguous vertebral body.
  • Preserved disc height
  • Absence of facet joint ankylosis or SI joint fusion.

questions.text: Identify the fracture site in the Xray shown below.
questions.solution:
There is evidence of displaced fracture of left 5th and 6th rib on posterior aspect.

Imaging techniques for diagnosing rib fractures typically include:

Plain Radiography (X-ray): This is often the first imaging modality used. However, it may miss up to 50% of rib fractures even with dedicated oblique rib projections.

Ultrasound: It is more sensitive and specific than conventional radiography for rib fracture detection in blunt trauma when performed by a trained clinician. It can also detect radiographically occult costal cartilage fractures and assess the underlying lung for associated traumatic pathology.

Computed Tomography (CT) Scan: A definitive diagnosis of rib fractures can be made with a CT scan. Advanced imaging like CT is often not necessary for isolated (one or two ribs) fractures once associated injury has been adequately excluded, typically with a chest radiograph.

These imaging methods help in the accurate diagnosis and management of rib fractures, ensuring proper treatment and monitoring for any potential complications.

Reference:

  1. Rib fractures | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org. https://radiopaedia.org/articles/rib-fractures.
  2. Initial evaluation and management of rib fractures - UpToDate. https://www.uptodate.com/contents/initial-evaluation-and-management-of-rib-fractures.
  3. Rib Fracture (Broken Rib): Symptoms, Healing Tips & Treatment. https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/17434-rib-fracture-broken-rib.
  4. Rib fractures - Symptoms, diagnosis and treatment - BMJ Best Practice. https://bestpractice.bmj.com/crawler/topics/en-gb/1009.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient has met with a road traffic accident and now presented to emergency in an unconscious state with following CT findings. Which of the following will be most useful step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Rationale:

  1. Unconscious State:The patient's unconsciousness following a traumatic event raises concerns for potential life-threatening injuries, particularly intracranial hemorrhage or significant traumatic brain injury.
  2. CT Findings:Although the specific CT findings are not detailed, in cases of trauma, especially with loss of consciousness, urgent surgical intervention may be necessary if there is evidence of mass effect, hemorrhage, or other critical injuries that require immediate attention.
  3. Emergency Protocol:The management of trauma patients typically follows the Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) guidelines, which prioritize rapid assessment and intervention for life-threatening conditions. If the CT scan indicates significant intracranial injury or other surgical emergencies, immediate surgery is warranted.
  4. Other Options:
    • Observation with serial imaging:This is not appropriate for an unconscious patient with potential serious injuries.
    • Neurological monitoring:While important, it does not address immediate life-threatening conditions that may require surgical intervention.
    • IV Mannitol:This may be used to manage increased intracranial pressure but is not the first step in the acute management of a potentially unstable patient

Reference: https://easletters.com/article/an-overview-on-diagnostic-and-management-approach-of-road-traffic-accidents-in-emergency-department-7w5wwvflqlra48j.

questions.text: 'Target material' which produces X-rays in a diagnostic X-rays tube is made of:
questions.solution:
Tungsten

  • Tungsten is preferred due to its high melting point and good heat conductivity, which are essential for with standing the high temperatures generated during X-ray production.

(Choices A, C and D) Lead, Cobalt and Copper are not used as Target material.

questions.text: Functional MRI was done for a stroke patient. What is the principle behind this Functional MRI?
questions.solution:
Functional MRI

  • Evaluates functional areas of Brain
  • Evaluates speech centres, fine motor areas, visual centres.
  • For Brain mapping
  • Based on BOLD technique "Blood O2 level dependent"

During a particular activity, the corresponding brain area will have increased oxygen consumption. Thus, this type of MRI helps in the detection of functions of different brain parts.

(Choice A) CT scan works on the principle of Linear attenuation of X rays not the Functional MR.

(Choice B) MR angiogrpahy works on the principle of Time of fight technique not the Functional MR.


(Choice D) Radioactive Iodine Uptake studies works on the principle of Uptake of radioactive Iodine technique not the Functional MR.

questions.text: Half-life of Iodine 123 is
questions.solution:
The half life of I 123 is 13 hrs

It is used for Radioactive Iodine uptake (RAIU) studies/ scintigraphy, it's a functional scan


(Choice A) I 124 has a half life of 4 days where as the half life of I 123 is 13 hrs.

(Choice B) I 131 has a half life of 8 days not the half life of I 123 is 13 hrs.

(Choice C) I 124 has a half life of 4 weeks not the half life of I 123 is 13 hrs.

questions.text: What is the Frequency of sound waves used for transabdominal ultrasonography is?
questions.solution:
The frequency of sound waves used for transabdominal ultrasonography is:3.5-5.0 MHz

Transabdominal ultrasonography: This imaging technique typically utilizes lower frequency sound waves, typically in the range of 3.5 to 5.0 MHz, to penetrate through the abdominal wall and visualize deep structures such as the uterus, ovaries, and abdominal organs.

LET'S REVISE:

  • Routine abdominal USG - 3.5 - 5 MHz
  • Transvaginal/Transrectal USG - 5 - 7.5 MHz
  • Superficial (orbit, thyroid, breast) USG - 8 - 12 MHz
  • Endoscopic USG - 12 - 20 MHz.

(Choice A, C and D) transabdominal ultrasonography uses 3.5-5.0 MHz waves, not the 2.5-3.5 MHz, 5.0-7.5 MHz and 7.5-10 MHz waves.

questions.text: Walls of the CT scanner room are coated with:
questions.solution:
Lead

Walls of the CT scanner room are coated with Lead

Lead is used because of it's ability to provide radiation shielding.

Lead can effectively attenuate certain kinds of radiation because of its high density and atomic number.

MRI room is made of copper containing cage called Faradays Cage, to avoid the radio frequency interface.

(Choices A, C and D) Walls of the CT scanner room are not coated with Glass, Tungsten and Iron as they cant provide the radiation shielding.

choices.text: Reversal of blood flow in the ipsilateral vertebral artery
Reversal of blood flow in the contralateral carotid artery
Reversal of blood flow in the contralateral vertebral artery
Bilateral reversal of blood flow in the vertebral arteries

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding subclavian steal syndrome?
questions.solution:
Reversal of blood flow in the ipsilateral vertebral artery

In subclavian steal syndrome, the stenosis or occlusion of the subclavian artery causes a pressure drop distal to the blockage. To compensate, blood flows retrograde (in the opposite direction) down the ipsilateral vertebral artery to supply the affected arm. This 'stealing' of blood can lead to symptoms of vertebrobasilar insufficiency and arm ischemia.

Subclavian steal syndrome is a condition that involves a reversal of blood flow in one of the vertebral arteries. This occurs due to a significant stenosis or occlusion of the subclavian artery proximal to the origin of the vertebral artery. As a result, blood flow is 'stolen' from the vertebral artery to supply the arm, bypassing the occluded segment.

The other options are incorrect because they do not describe the characteristic flow dynamics of subclavian steal syndrome:

(Choices B and C) Reversal of blood flow in the contralateral carotid artery or vertebral artery does not occur in subclavian steal syndrome.

(Choice D) Bilateral reversal of blood flow in the vertebral arteries is not typical of this condition.

questions.text: Left atrial hypertrophy is seen radiologically as:
questions.solution:
Left atrial enlargement - Straightening of left heart border, elevated left mainstem bronchus, widening of carinal angle, double atrial shadow or density, impression on esophagus seen in Ba swallow.


(Choice A, B C and D) Double atrial shadow, Left bronchial elevation and Straightening of left heart border are seen in Left atrial hypertrophy.

questions.text: A 5 year old child presented with bleeding gums and swollen knee joints. He underwent a knee x-ray which is shown below.identify the marked finding used to diagnose the condition ?
questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows radio-opaque line known as Frenkel's line along with the history of bleeding gums in a child will help in diagnosing it as a case of scurvy.

Radiographic features of scurvy

  • generalized osteopenia
  • cortical thinning: "pencil-point" cortex
  • periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • scorbutic rosary: expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • may relate to the fracturing of the zone of provisional calcification during normal respiration
  • similar to the rachitic rosary appearance as seen in rickets
  • hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger's ring sign: circular, opaque radiologic shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frankel line: dense zone of provisional calcification
  • Trummerfeld zone: lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelkan spur: metaphyseal spurs that result in cupping of the metaphysis
  • Pelkan fracture: metaphyseal corner fracture

(Choice B) 'Looser"s zones,' also known as pseudofractures, can be characteristically seen in osteomalacia.


(Choices C and D): Fraying of metaphyses and Cupping of epiphyses is seen in

questions.text: Which abnormality is represented in the radiological image given below?
questions.solution:
Spondylolisthesis

X-ray shows Beheaded scottish dog appearance Spondylolisthesis


  • The Scottie dog sign refers to the normal appearance of the lumbar spine when seen on oblique radiographic projection.
  • Scotty dog with collar is seen in spondylolysis.

(Choice A) Scottie dog sign refers to the normal appearance of the lumbar spine when seen on oblique radiographic projection, where as the given Xray shows Beheaded scottish dog appearance suggestive of Spondylolisthesis

(Choice B) Scotty dog with collar is seen in spondylolysis.where as the given Xray shows Beheaded scottish dog appearance suggestive of Spondylolisthesis.


(Choice D) Spondyloptosis is a rare and refers to a slippage of the L5 vertebra in which the entire vertebral body of L5 is located below the top of S1. It is the most severe degree of slippage possible.

questions.text: A patient presented with difficulty in swallowing of food. He gives a history of corrosive acid poisoning. He was advised to undergo a barium swallow which is shows below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given barium image shows a narrowing of the contrast column in the mid and distal esophagus. This along with a history of corrosive acid poisoning points to a diagnosis of corrosive stricture.

Where as in case of achalasia cardia the barium swallow shows a distended esophagus followed by thinning of the contrast column of the barium giving a bird beak appearance.

(Choice A): Tracheo-esophageal fistula


The above image shows a barium swallow of the esophagus. There is opacification of the tracheobronchial tree by the contrast. This occurs when the contrast passes from the esophagus to the trachea as occurs in TEF, where as the given X ray shows a narrowing of the contrast column in the mid and distal esophagus. This along with a history of corrosive acid poisoning points to a diagnosis of corrosive stricture.

(Choice B) Barium swallow irregularity narrowing esophageal lumen with mucosal lumen and shouldered margins. It is suggestive of esophageal carcinoma, where as the given X ray shows a narrowing of the contrast column in the mid and distal esophagus. This along with a history of corrosive acid poisoning points to a diagnosis of corrosive stricture.


(Choice C): achalasia cardia; the barium swallow shows a distended esophagus followed by thinning of the contrast column of the barium giving a bird beak appearance and is suggestive of achalasia cardia, where as the given X ray shows a narrowing of the contrast column in the mid and distal esophagus. This along with a history of corrosive acid poisoning points to a diagnosis of corrosive stricture.

questions.text: A 18 days old child is brought to the OPD with complaints of recurrent vomiting , On evaluation a olive shaped mass was found on abdominal examination , A USG is advised and shows the following sign , Identify the condition associated ?
questions.solution:
The given USG shows the cervix / antral nipple sign and is seen in case of Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS).

First born male child, > 3 weeks

  • Non bilious vomiting, palpable olive like mass at the epigastrium
  • Child has hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.

Ultrasound (USG) Findings:

Muscle Hypertrophy:

Thickening of the pyloric muscle is a hallmark feature. (> 3mm )

Pyloric Length:

Elongation of the pyloric channel is often observed. (>16 mm)

Double-Track or Railroad Track Sign:

Appearance of two parallel, echogenic (bright) lines on either side of the lumen.

Gives the characteristic "double-track" or "railroad track" appearance.


(Choice A) Intussusception is a condition in which one segment of intestine "telescopes" inside of another, causing an intestinal obstruction (blockage), it will show claw sign on barium studies and target sign on USG, where as the given USG shows cervix sign which is seen in case of IHPS.


(Choice B) In case of ileocecal tuberculosis, shows goose neck deformity. Goose neck deformity occurs due to contracted, cicatrized, and pulled-up cecum as well as straightening of terminal ileum, where as the given USG shows cervix sign which is seen in case of IHPS.


(Choice D) Hirschsprung disease shows narrowing of the distal most colon and proximal dilation of the colon, where as the given USG shows cervix sign which is seen in case of IHPS.

choices.text: Patient with Diabetic nephropathy on Metformin

questions.text: Radiocontrast agents are contraindicated in,
questions.solution:
• Radiocontrast agents are known to be associated with Contrast Induced Nephropathy and are Contraindicated in Renal Failure,Diabetic Nephropathy,Metformin Toxicity and in patients with Dehydration.
  • Single best step to Prevent Contrast induced nephropathy is Hydration.

(Choices A, B, C and D ) Radiocontrast agents are contraindicated in -Dehydration, Patient with Diabetic nephropathy on Metformin and Renal Failure.

questions.text: A patient presented with a cystic lesion in the liver on USG which is shown below and was diagnosed as a case of liver abscess Which of the following locations to be additionally evaluated to identify the source of the abscess ?
questions.solution:
Hepatic abscesses are localized collections of necrotic inflammatory tissue caused by bacterial, parasitic, or fungal agents. Hepatic abscesses can occur via different routes such as:

  • hematogenous spread of infection via the portal vein or hepatic arteries
  • biliary spread of infection from ascending cholangitis or cholecystitis
  • direct inoculation in the setting of penetrating trauma or iatrogenic following a procedure

ileocaecal junction and caecum should be evaluated to find out the amoebic involvement.

(Choices A,C and D ) They are not the common source of liver abscess so they are not evaluated routinely.

questions.text: A 35 year old woman presented to the emergency department with Upper abdominal pain radiating to the back. On Xray, the following finding is seen. What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
The Clinical feature of upper abdominal pain radiating to the back along with the Xray showing colon cutoff sign is suggestive of Acute Pancreatitis.

Imaging features of Acute Pancreatitis include Enlarged Pancreas with peripancreatic inflammatory changes, duct dilatation & acute fluid collections.

Other Radiological signs seen in Acute Pancreatitis are:

  • Gasless abdomen (due to repeated vomiting)
  • Sentinel Loop sign (Non-specific)
  • Small bowel ileus
  • Renal Halo sign on CT Scan




(Choice A) Acute Cholecystitis presents with RUQ pain typically after Meals an d radiologicallhy shows Gallbladder dilatation, gallstone obstructing the neck of GB, wall thickening, sonographic Murphy's sign.

(Choice B) Small Bowel Obstruction presents with diffuse abdomianl pain and radiologically shows Stepladder Pattern.


(Choice D) Hollow viscus perforation presents with diffuse abdomianl pain with shock and has Air under diaphragm sign. The management is Resuscitation followed by Laparotomy.

questions.text: Which MRI technique is used to localize Speech Centers in the Brain?
questions.solution:
Functional MRI is based on BOLD technique, Blood O2 Level Dependent technique and is used to localize speech centers and Brain Mapping

  • Measures brain activity by detecting changes in blood flow and oxygenation.
  • Visualizes functional changes in real-time during tasks or rest.
  • Offers insights into neural processes and connectivity.
  • Used for mapping brain regions related to specific functions.
  • Valuable tool in neuroimaging for clinical and research purposes.

(Choice A) Diffusion weighted MRI (DWI) is based on Brownian movements.It detects Cytotoxic Edema before Vasogenic Edema.

Diffusion Restriction - Bright signal on DWI, low Apparent Diffusion Coefficient (ADC)


(Choice B) Diffusion Tensor Imaging is Tractography. It uses anisotropic movements. Its evaluates White matter tracts


(Choice D) MR-Spectroscopy - Evaluates Chemical Metabolites in Brain

Normal Hunters angle is 45 degrees


  • Choline peak@3.2ppm is seen in Tumors
  • Lipid-Lactate peak @1ppm is seen in Tuberculoma
  • N-Acetyl aspartate peak @2ppm is seen in CANAVAN'S Disease

choices.text: Take a biopsy from the lesion

questions.text: A patient with recent history of weight loss and fatigue came to OPD for routine follow up. He underwent a USG examination of the abdomen. The images of the liver are shown below. The previous USG done 6 months ago showed a normal appearance of the liver. What should be the next best step in this patient ?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows a target appearance of multiple lesions in the liver parenchyma. It is suggestive of liver metastasis.
  • Hypoechoic: most common ~65%
    • lung cancer
    • breast cancer
    • pancreatic adenocarcinoma
    • lymphoma
  • hyperechoic
    • colorectal carcinoma (CRC)
    • renal cell carcinoma (RCC)
    • choriocarcinoma
    • Kaposi sarcoma
    • neuroendocrine tumors
    • carcinoid
    • pancreatic islet cell tumors
  • peripheral halo: a hypoechoic halo is a concerning feature, sometimes called the target or bull's eye lesion/sign
    • common in many
    • lung cancer
  • calcified
    • mucinous adenocarcinoma
    • gastrointestinal
    • ovarian mucinous adenocarcinoma
  • cystic
    • squamous cell carcinoma
    • ovarian cancer
    • pancreatic adenocarcinoma
    • colorectal carcinoma (CRC)
  • poorly defined (infiltrative)
    • melanoma
    • breast cancer
    • lung cancer
  • associated intrahepatic biliary dilation
    • colorectal carcinoma (CRC)

(Choices A and D): The history of loss of weight along with USG findings is suggestive of Metastasis, So the work up for this should be done to find out the primary source and there is no role of antibiotics in it.

(Choice B): As the given image shows the metastasis, the next step is to identify the primary source and take biopsy from it not from the secondary source in liver.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman falls in the bathroom and hurts her head. She regains her consciousness after a few minutes, and continues with her daily activities. After three hours, she again becomes unconscious and collapses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes lucid interval, and it is classically associated with Extradural/Epidural haemorrhage (EDH).

Patients with EDH present with 3 phases:

  • The patient is initially unconscious from the concussive aspect of the head trauma (Cerebral concussion).
  • The patient then awakens (recovery from concussive effect) and has a lucid interval while the hematoma sub-clinically expands.
  • As the volume of the hematoma grows, intracranial pressure (ICP) increases, and the patient rapidly becomes lethargic and unconscious.

The latent interval may be of variable duration and, as just noted, may not occur if either concussion is prolonged or other brain damage coexists. Half an hour may be enough for the formation of a significant arterial haematoma, though some slow bleeds have taken more than a day to become clinically apparent.

Lucid interval is seen only in 30-40% of cases.

A lucid interval is a period of normal consciousness and here the person is legally bound by the laws that affect normal people.

Extradural haematoma (EDH) is defined as an acute haemorrhage between the dura mater and the inner surface of the skull. An EDH can cause compression of the local brain structures and a rise in intracranial pressure. If intracranial pressure continues to rise, cerebellar herniation may occur leading to brainstem death.

questions.text: A young boy was brought to the orthopaedic department with complaints of repetitive fractures along with tenderness in the bones, fatigue, short stature, walking difficulty and muscle cramps. His radiological signs are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most suitable vitamin D preparation for vitamin D dependent rickets?
questions.solution:
(a) Vit D resistant rickets: X-linked hereditary disease in which vit D metabolism is normal but calcium and phosphate metabolism is deranged. Administration of phosphate with high doses of calcitriol or alfacalcidol is beneficial.

(b) Vit D dependent rickets: Another genetic disorder due to deficiency of renal hydroxylating mechanism which converts 25-OHD3 into calcitriol.

Administration of calcitriol or alfacalcidol is effective in normal doses.

(c) Renal rickets: Conversion of 25-OHD3 into calcitriol (which takes place in the kidney) does not occur due to chronic renal disease. Calcitriol/ alfacalcidol or dihydrotachysterol are needed in usual doses.

questions.text: Ultrasound works based on the principle of?
questions.solution:
The principle used in ultrasound machines is: Piezoelectric crystal excitation

Ultrasound/sonographic/echographic Image is based on mechanical oscillations of the crystal excited by electrical pulses (piezoelectric effect).

The tip of ultrasound transducer is made up of piezoelectric crystals like lead zirconate titanate.

When electric current pass through the transducer, these crystals starts to vibrate and produces ultrasound waves.

They propagate through different tissues and is reflected back. These waves are then converted back into electrical impulses by the transducer crystals. This is called piezoelectric effect. These impulses are further processed to form an ultrasound image on the screen by pulse-echo principle.

(Choice B) Very low frequency radiowaves/radiowaves are used in the MRI scan not in Ultrasound.

(Choice C) Microwaves are not used in the Ultrasound.

(Choice D) Linear attenuation of X rays are used in the CT scan not in Ultrasound.
